body:
Finan of Lindisfarne

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search

"Finan" redirects here. For the surname, see Finan (surname) .
Finan of Lindisfarne
Bishop of Lindisfarne
Installed 651
Term ended 661
Predecessor Aidan
Successor Colmán
Personal details
Born Ireland
Died 17 February 661
Lindisfarne
Denomination Christian
Sainthood
Feast day 17 February, 9 February

Finan of Lindisfarne (died 10 [1] or 17 February 661), also known as Saint Finan , was an Irish monk , trained at Iona Abbey in Scotland, who became the second Bishop of Lindisfarne from 651 until 661.

Contents

  • 1 Life
  • 2 Veneration
  • 3 Citations
  • 4 References
  • 5 External links

Life [ edit ]

Finan was appointed to Lindisfarne in 651. [2]

Originally from Ireland, he built on Lindisfarne, a cathedral "in the Irish fashion", employing hewn oak, with a thatched roof, dedicated to St. Peter. He also founded St. Mary's at the mouth of the River Tyne. [3] He converted the kings Sigebert of Essex [4] and Peada of the Middle Angles to Christianity . [5] Bede is the main source for Finan's life. [4] He is specially noted by Bede as having borne an important part in the conversion of the northern Saxons. [6]

The breviary of Aberdeen styles him "a man of venerable life, a bishop of great sanctity, an eloquent teacher ... remarkable for his training in virtue and his liberal education, surpassing all his equals in every manner of knowledge as well as in circumspection and prudence, but chiefly devoting himself to good works and presenting in his life, a most apt example of virtue". [3] Finan ordained St. Cedd bishop of the East-Saxons, having called two other bishops to assist at his consecration.

The Abbey of Whitby, his chief foundation, was the scene of the famous Paschal controversy, which resulted in the withdrawal of the Irish monks from Lindisfarne. [3]

Finan was active for some time at a monastery on Church Island on Lough Currane in County Kerry ; today it is known as St. Finan's Church. To the south of the lake is Inis Uasal (Noble Island), an island which is dedicated to him. [7]

Finan died in 661, [2] and was buried at Lindisfarne, having held that see ten years.

Veneration [ edit ]

Finan's feast day is celebrated upon 9 January. [6]

Citations [ edit ]

  1. ^ Saint Cuthbert: With an Account of the State in which His Remains Were Found Upon the Opening of His Tomb in Durham Cathedral, in the Year MDCCCXXVII . G. Andrews. 1928. p. 11.
  2. ^ a b Fryde, et al. Handbook of British Chronology p. 219
  3. ^ a b c Grattan-Flood, William. "St. Finan." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 6. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1909. 12 May 2013
  4. ^ a b Walsh New Dictionary of Saints p. 203
  5. ^ Kirby Earliest English Kings pp. 79–80
  6. ^ a b Webb, Alfred. A Compendium of Irish Biography , M. H. Gill & Son, Dublin, 1878
  7. ^ Carver, Martin (2006). The cross goes north: processes of conversion in northern Europe, AD 300-1300 . Boydell Press. p. 134. ISBN 1-84383-125-2 .

References [ edit ]

  • Fryde, E. B.; Greenway, D. E.; Porter, S.; Roy, I. (1996). Handbook of British Chronology (Third revised ed.). Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-56350-X .
  • Kirby, D. P. (2000). The Earliest English Kings . New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-24211-8 .
  • Walsh, Michael A New Dictionary of Saints: East and West London: Burns & Oats 2007 ISBN 0-86012-438-X

Finan of Lindisfarne Bishop of Lindisfarne Installed 651 Term ended 661 Predecessor Aidan Successor Colmán Personal details Born Ireland Died 17 February 661 Lindisfarne Denomination Christian Sainthood Feast day 17 February, 9 February Finan of Lindisfarne (died 10 [1] or 17 February 661), also known as Saint Finan , was an Irish monk , trained at Iona Abbey in Scotland, who became the second Bishop of Lindisfarne from 651 until 661. Contents 1 Life 2 Veneration 3 Citations 4 References 5 External links Life [ edit ] Finan was appointed to Lindisfarne in 651. [2] Originally from Ireland, he built on Lindisfarne, a cathedral "in the Irish fashion", employing hewn oak, with a thatched roof, dedicated to St. Peter. He also founded St. Mary's at the mouth of the River Tyne. [3] He converted the kings Sigebert of Essex [4] and Peada of the Middle Angles to Christianity . [5] Bede is the main source for Finan's life. [4] He is specially noted by Bede as having borne an important part in the conversion of the northern Saxons. [3] Finan ordained St. Cedd bishop of the East-Saxons, having called two other bishops to assist at his consecration. The Abbey of Whitby, his chief foundation, was the scene of the famous Paschal controversy, which resulted in the withdrawal of the Irish monks from Lindisfarne. [3] Finan was active for some time at a monastery on Church Island on Lough Currane in County Kerry ; today it is known as St. Finan's Church. To the south of the lake is Inis Uasal (Noble Island), an island which is dedicated to him. [7] Finan died in 661, [2] and was buried at Lindisfarne, having held that see ten years. Veneration [ edit ] Finan's feast day is celebrated upon 9 January.
